wp_post.post_content:
Alongside the core course material, this section provides extra tools to deepen your understanding.

Included Resources

  • November 2020 Masterclass: A live session covering advanced fingerstyle techniques.
  • May 2021 Masterclass: Further insights into improvisation and applying tribal fingerstyle techniques.
  • Songs of the Nations (Album Download): A collection of tracks to study and play along with.
  • The Sound of Tribal Congo (Ebook): A deep dive into the historical and cultural context of tribal guitar playing.

Northern Congo is home to the Ba Ngala people, whose music is known for its fast-paced, circular guitar patterns. Their playing style features syncopated polyrhythms, making use of rapid left-hand movement and a unique way of structuring melodies.

Learning Focus

  • Learning the core patterns of the Ba Ngala guitar tradition.
  • Breaking down melodic variations and rhythmic phrasing.
  • Combining all elements into a cohesive performance.

Cultural & Musical Context

Ba Ngala music is deeply rooted in dance and social gatherings, where the guitar serves as the foundation for long, hypnotic grooves. The fast, repetitive motifs reflect the energy and spirit of communal celebration.
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 - The Sounds Of The Ba Ngala

wp_post.post_content:
The Ba Kongo people developed a distinct approach to guitar playing, emphasizing intricate chord-melody arrangements and flowing melodic lines. This module introduces the harmonic and technical elements behind their style.

Learning Focus

  • Developing independence between bass, melody, and chordal movement.
  • Understanding the Ba Kongo right-hand five-finger technique.
  • Creating fluid movement across the fretboard with chord-melody phrasing.

Cultural & Musical Context

The Ba Kongo style of guitar is deeply linked to their traditional vocal music, where melodies move in call-and-response patterns. The guitar adapts this approach, imitating the interwoven nature of voices in a choir.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - The Music Of The Ba Kongo

wp_post.post_content:
Tribal fingerstyle guitar has evolved across generations, developing unique right-hand techniques that make the guitar sound like an entire ensemble. This module introduces you to foundational elements of this approach, including how melodies interact with basslines and rhythmic cycles.

Learning Focus

  • Introduction to Congolese rumba and its evolution.
  • Understanding African melodic phrasing using basic scales.
  • Learning essential intervals and their role in African guitar traditions.

Cultural & Musical Context

Congolese guitar evolved as part of an oral tradition, influenced by traditional folk music, Cuban son, and jazz. Rumba music, led by figures like Franco Luambo Makiadi and Tabu Ley, redefined African guitar playing by merging rhythmic complexity with lyrical expression.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - An Introduction To Tribal Guitar Styles

wp_post.post_content:
Module Overview

This section provides professionally recorded backing tracks in Maskandi and other South African styles, allowing you to apply the techniques and grooves learned throughout the course in a real musical setting.

wp_post.post_content:
Module Overview

This section features an in-depth live masterclass with South African bass legend Bakithi Kumalo, known for his groundbreaking work with Paul Simon on Graceland. It provides valuable insight into groove, tone, and musical philosophy from one of Africa’s most influential bassists.

Module Overview

This module focuses on essential theory and technical skills that will improve your overall bass playing. It covers foundational concepts, fretboard fluency, and practical exercises for precision and control.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding interval relationships and how they apply to basslines.
  • Practicing scale exercises with African phrasing techniques.
  • Improving dexterity and articulation for more fluid bass playing.
  • Strengthening rhythmic independence and left-hand coordination.

Module Overview

This module expands on the bass styles covered so far, offering a deeper exploration of South African musical traditions. You’ll refine your ability to groove within various styles, improving your adaptability as a bassist.

Learning Focus

  • Applying previously learned techniques to new South African repertoire.
  • Strengthening improvisational skills within different rhythmic structures.
  • Enhancing your ability to lock in with a band while maintaining groove consistency.
wp_post.post_title: Module 14 - Further South African Bass Study

wp_post.post_content:
Module Overview

This module explores the expressive basslines of Maskandi, a storytelling-driven Zulu folk style, and Ghoema, a vibrant Cape jazz-influenced rhythm. You’ll study how basslines interact with harmonic movement and percussive drive in both traditions.

Learning Focus

  • Learning the characteristic bass phrasing of Maskandi, including melodic and percussive techniques.
  • Developing a strong sense of Ghoema rhythm, known for its syncopated and swinging feel.
  • Strengthening right-hand articulation to execute intricate grooves accurately.

Cultural & Musical Context

Maskandi is a Zulu music tradition deeply rooted in storytelling, often featuring a solo guitarist accompanying sung narratives. The basslines in this style are highly melodic, mimicking the vocal lines. Ghoema, originating in Cape Town’s mixed-race communities, is rhythmically complex and forms the foundation of South African jazz. Its bass parts drive the groove with a playful, rolling feel.

Module Overview

This module introduces two of South Africa’s most distinctive and influential styles: Mbaqanga and Marabi. You will learn how the bassline acts as the foundation for these energetic and highly rhythmic genres, driving the groove while interweaving with other instruments.

Learning Focus

  • Developing fluency in Mbaqanga’s walking bass and offbeat phrasing.
  • Understanding Marabi’s cyclical bass patterns and their role in improvisation.
  • Strengthening rhythmic accuracy and note articulation for both styles.

Cultural & Musical Context

Mbaqanga emerged in South Africa’s townships in the 1960s, blending jazz, Zulu traditional music, and pop influences. The bassline is the driving force, often bouncing between groove and melodic function. Marabi, an older style, laid the groundwork for South African jazz, characterized by its repetitive, danceable chord progressions designed to keep parties going for hours.

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

South African music has a distinct feel, with basslines that are often melodic and uplifting. This module introduces foundational South African grooves.

Learning Focus

  • Playing basslines that interact with vocal harmonies
  • Understanding the relaxed feel of South African grooves
  • Developing melodic movement within rhythm sections

Cultural and Musical Context

From Mbaqanga to Maskandi, South African music places a strong emphasis on storytelling and melody. The basslines often mirror vocal phrases, making them integral to the song’s identity.
wp_post.post_title: Module 11 - Introduction To South African Music

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

Afrobeat is a genre where basslines take center stage. This module explores how to create powerful, rhythmic Afrobeat bass grooves.

Learning Focus

  • Learning key Afrobeat bass patterns
  • Developing long, flowing grooves that drive the music
  • Creating variation while maintaining a locked-in feel

Cultural and Musical Context

Fela Kuti pioneered Afrobeat in the 1970s, blending highlife, jazz, and funk with deep, hypnotic bass grooves. The bass in Afrobeat is repetitive but constantly shifting in subtle ways to maintain movement.

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

Basslines in African music are built from improvisation and feel. This module focuses on developing authentic, natural-sounding grooves from scratch.

Learning Focus

  • Constructing basslines that feel organic and natural
  • Understanding syncopation in different African styles
  • Strengthening the connection between bass and drums

Cultural and Musical Context

In African music, bass players rarely play the same groove twice. Variations and improvisations are what keep the energy alive, making every performance unique.

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

This module takes a deeper dive into the technical aspects of Congolese Soukous bass, refining tone, stamina, and technique.

Learning Focus

  • Strengthening stamina for fast-paced basslines
  • Developing articulation and clean note execution
  • Practicing brain independence for complex rhythmic coordination

Cultural and Musical Context

Soukous developed from Congolese Rumba, evolving into a fast-paced, dance-driven style with rapid, rolling basslines that push the energy of the music.

Overview

African Salsa and Rumba bring Latin influences into the African musical landscape. This module explores how the tumbao bass pattern evolved within African dance music.

Learning Focus

  • Learning the fundamentals of salsa bass grooves
  • Applying African phrasing to tumbao variations
  • Understanding clave and its relationship to bass movement

Cultural and Musical Context

Salsa and Rumba originated in the Caribbean but were heavily influenced by African rhythms. Many African bands adopted these styles, incorporating them into their own musical traditions.

Overview

Mbalax, Senegal’s most distinctive popular music, blends traditional sabar drumming with modern bass and guitar. This module teaches how to integrate bass into the polyrhythmic layers of Mbalax.

Learning Focus

  • Developing tight, syncopated basslines for Mbalax
  • Playing with dynamic energy to match sabar drumming
  • Locking into the interplay between bass and percussion

Cultural and Musical Context

Mbalax evolved in the 1970s, spearheaded by artists like Youssou N’Dour. The bass in Mbalax is fast, rhythmic, and works in tandem with the complex drum rhythms of sabar players.

Overview

Griot music from West Africa carries deep cultural and historical significance, often led by the kora, balafon, or ngoni. This module teaches how to accompany traditional griot melodies on bass.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding the role of the bass in griot ensembles
  • Playing call-and-response patterns with melodic instruments
  • Developing phrasing to complement kora and balafon lines

Cultural and Musical Context

Griots are the oral historians of West Africa, preserving traditions through music and storytelling. Their music is deeply polyrhythmic, and the bass must weave between melody and percussion to create a seamless groove.

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

Many well-known pop and rock basslines can be reinterpreted through an African rhythmic lens. This module explores how to adapt familiar grooves with new rhythmic phrasing and feel.

Learning Focus

  • Applying Soukous, Afrobeat, and Zouk techniques to pop basslines
  • Shifting rhythmic emphasis to create a more danceable groove
  • Understanding how African phrasing transforms familiar music

Cultural and Musical Context

The influence of African rhythms on global music is undeniable. From Michael Jackson to The Beatles, many classic basslines contain rhythmic elements that can be traced back to African traditions.
wp_post.post_title: Module 4 - Translate Pop Basslines Into African

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

Zouk, originating from the French Caribbean, made its way back to Africa and became an essential groove in dance music. This module breaks down the flowing, syncopated basslines that define Zouk.

Learning Focus

  • Developing a smooth and fluid approach to bass phrasing
  • Understanding how chord tones drive bassline movement
  • Playing syncopated rhythms that lock in with percussion

Cultural and Musical Context

Zouk music has strong ties to the African diaspora, blending Caribbean, African, and French influences. The bass in Zouk is less about complex variation and more about steady, locked-in grooves that make the music feel effortless and danceable.

Overview

Zimbabwean basslines are built around melodic movement, often mimicking traditional mbira (thumb piano) patterns. This module explores the intricate, interwoven style of Sungura and Chimurenga bass.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding arpeggiated basslines and their connection to mbira music
  • Playing Sungura grooves with speed and fluidity
  • Adding variations to create momentum in Chimurenga rhythms

Cultural and Musical Context

Zimbabwean music is deeply rooted in storytelling and dance. Sungura is a high-energy style with rapid-fire basslines, while Chimurenga carries a powerful historical and political message through its hypnotic repetitions.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - How To Play Zimbabwean Music

wp_post.post_content:
Overview

Soukous and Sebene are at the heart of Congolese dance music, known for their hypnotic, interlocking basslines that drive the rhythm. This module introduces you to the fundamental techniques and variations used by top Congolese bassists.

Learning Focus

  • Developing precision and stamina for fast, repetitive basslines
  • Mastering the Congolese thumb technique for rhythmic drive
  • Creating and layering variations to enhance groove

Cultural and Musical Context

Congolese music evolved from early Rumba influences into high-energy Soukous and Sebene, designed to keep dancers moving for hours. The bass does more than support the music—it interacts with the guitars and percussion, shaping the entire groove.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - Learn Soukous And Sebene Bass

wp_post.post_content:
Festejo and Landó are among Peru’s most rhythmically complex styles, reflecting the deep influence of African musical traditions on Peruvian culture.

Learning Focus

  • Learn percussive guitar techniques unique to Afro-Peruvian music.
  • Develop a strong rhythmic feel with syncopation and polyrhythms.
  • Study essential Festejo and Landó repertoire.

Cultural & Musical Context

During the colonial era, enslaved Africans in Peru preserved their musical traditions through percussion and dance, which later evolved into the Afro-Peruvian genres of Festejo and Landó. Today, these styles are celebrated for their powerful rhythms and expressive storytelling.

Carnavalito is a high-energy festival dance, while the Peruvian waltz blends European elegance with Creole soul. This module teaches fast, percussive strumming alongside delicate, expressive phrasing.

Learning Focus

  • Capture the syncopated drive of Carnavalito.
  • Develop smooth, flowing articulation for Peruvian waltz.
  • Learn essential embellishments and ornaments.

Cultural & Musical Context

Carnavalito is performed during Indigenous celebrations across Peru, Bolivia, and northern Argentina. Peruvian waltz, popularized by Chabuca Granda, became a cornerstone of Peruvian Creole music.

Sonqollay introduces advanced fingerstyle techniques, showcasing how Peruvian guitarists layer melody and bass to create self-sufficient solo arrangements.

Learning Focus

  • Master fingerstyle independence, balancing melody and bass.
  • Learn chord-melody techniques for solo guitar.
  • Develop dynamic phrasing for emotional expression.

Cultural & Musical Context

Sonqollay is deeply poetic and melodic, often performed by singer-songwriters or instrumentalists evoking the landscapes and emotions of the Peruvian highlands.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 – Sonqollay: The Art of Fingerstyle Guitar

wp_post.post_content:
Huayño is one of the most iconic styles of the Peruvian Andes, with deep Indigenous roots that date back centuries. Traditionally accompanied by flutes, violins, and percussion, Huayño’s guitar adaptation brings out its bright, syncopated strumming patterns and melodic phrasing.

Learning Focus

  • Develop Huayño strumming techniques and rhythmic precision.
  • Understand syncopation and its role in Andean music.
  • Learn a traditional Huayño melody and variations.

Cultural & Musical Context

Huayño originated in Quechua and Aymara communities of the Andean highlands. It became a national symbol of Peruvian identity in the 20th century and remains one of the most widely performed folk styles across Bolivia, Ecuador, and Peru.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 – Huayño: The Heartbeat of Andean Music

wp_post.post_content:
Step into the world of Rebetiko, often called the "Greek Blues." Fernando teaches the melody of his composition O Elenikos Filos Mou and shows how to emulate the bouzouki on guitar. You’ll also learn the Zeybekiko rhythm and the Dorian Augmented 4th scale, capturing the soulful essence of this style.

Learning Focus:

  • Emulate the bouzouki’s sound and phrasing on guitar.
  • Learn the Zeybekiko rhythm and Dorian Augmented 4th scale.
  • Improvise expressively within the Rebetiko tradition.

Context & References:

Rebetiko, often compared to American blues, emerged from Greece’s urban working-class communities in the early 20th century. It features deeply emotive lyrics and improvisational instrumental sections, often led by the bouzouki, a long-necked lute. The Zeybekiko rhythm, a slow 9/8, is integral to Rebetiko, emphasizing individuality and emotional depth.

Suggested Listening:

  • Cloudy Sunday by Vasilis Tsitsanis

_oembed_b3af1d9e42d844a36798ac0e19ee9c65: <iframe title="Vasilis Tsitsanis - Συννεφιασμένη Κυριακή / Cloudy Sunday (English lyrics) 1941" width="640" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/wJDg_aXS_7U?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe>

wp_post.post_content:
Explore the fiery energy of Spanish Rumba, inspired by Flamenco traditions. Fernando teaches his composition Alexandrina, breaking down rumba rhythms, Flamenco cadence chords, and advanced techniques like Alzapua and Golpe. You’ll even learn a Paco de Lucía-style break, blending modern and traditional influences.

Learning Focus:

  • Master rumba rhythms and Flamenco strumming techniques.
  • Incorporate advanced techniques like Alzapua and Golpe.
  • Perform with dynamic breaks inspired by Paco de Lucía.

Context & References:

Rumba Flamenca is a lively style of Flamenco with Afro-Cuban influences. Popularized by artists like Paco de Lucía, it is known for its driving rhythms and percussive strumming techniques. The Alzapua technique is a hallmark of Flamenco, blending bass, melody, and rhythm into a single, fluid motion.

Suggested Listening:

  • Entre Dos Aguas by Paco de Lucía

Discover the beauty of Egyptian music as Fernando transforms the guitar into an oud, the iconic Arabic stringed instrument. Learn the Nubian scale, taqsim improvisation, and the malfuf rhythm, while exploring thumb tremolo techniques to evoke authentic Middle Eastern sounds.

Learning Focus:

  • Replicate the sound and phrasing of the Arabic oud on guitar.
  • Master the Nubian scale and taqsim improvisation.
  • Incorporate the malfuf rhythm and thumb tremolo into your playing.

Context & References:

The oud is central to Arabic music, known for its warm, resonant sound and melodic expressiveness. Fernando’s approach adapts this iconic sound to the guitar, drawing inspiration from his time in Alexandria, Egypt. The malfuf rhythm, commonly used in traditional Arabic music, is a lively 2/4 rhythm that accompanies festive and ceremonial events.

Suggested Listening:

  • City Of Daffodils by Naseer Shamma

Dive into the lively world of Rachenitza, a Bulgarian dance rhythm in 7/8 time. Fernando demonstrates how to feel the rhythm intuitively through its dance-like phrasing and teaches a composition inspired by this tradition. From mastering melodic ornaments to harmonizing with rhythmic drive, this module builds your fluency in odd-metered playing.

Learning Focus:

  • Understand the 7/8 time signature through intuitive phrasing.
  • Master Bulgarian melodic ornaments and harmonization techniques.
  • Develop rhythmic precision and drive for odd-metered pieces.

Context & References:

Rachenitza is a traditional Bulgarian folk dance performed in 7/8 time, characterized by its short-short-long pattern. The rhythm is deeply tied to the movement of dancers, who step to this pattern in vibrant community gatherings. As part of Bulgaria’s rich musical heritage, Rachenitza reflects the country's historical blending of Eastern and Western influences.

Check out the rhythm of the dancers steps in this video to see how they feel the music.

Malian guitar isn’t just about playing notes—it’s about telling a story, responding to the rhythm, and understanding the music’s deeper purpose. This final module ties everything together, giving you the tools to think, feel, and play like a Malian musician.

Learning Focus:

  • Developing a storytelling approach to improvisation.
  • Understanding the difference between live and studio playing.
  • Building your own Malian-inspired guitar voice.

Cultural & Musical Context:

In Mali, music is not just entertainment—it’s a spiritual and cultural force. Griots use song to preserve history, and improvisation is not about showing off—it’s about evoking emotions, responding to the moment, and bringing the audience into the groove.
wp_post.post_title: Module 7 – Mastering the Malian Guitar Mindset

wp_post.post_content:
Central Mali’s music is faster and more rhythmically complex than its northern counterpart. This module focuses on syncopation, speed, and dynamic interplay between the guitar and percussion.

Learning Focus:

  • Studying double-gum octave techniques for fluidity and speed.
  • Locking into fast calabash grooves with precision.
  • Exploring Bwa rhythms and their influence on Malian guitar phrasing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

The Bwa people are known for their polyrhythmic drumming, and their influence on Malian guitar is undeniable. The interplay between talking drums and balafon melodies has shaped the octave-based phrasing and percussive attack heard in Central Malian styles.
wp_post.post_title: Module 6 – Central Mali: Rhythmic Power & Speed

wp_post.post_content:
The music of Northern Mali is hypnotic, trance-like, and deeply rhythmic. This module explores the rolling grooves of Takamba and the driving energy of Tuareg Desert Blues, showing you how to develop the percussive phrasing that defines Saharan guitar.

Learning Focus:

  • Mastering Takamba’s pulsing, danceable groove.
  • Understanding Tuareg guitar’s open-string drones and syncopated rhythms.
  • Learning how to layer melodies over repetitive basslines.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Takamba music is played by the Songhai people and is known for its percussive, trance-inducing rhythms, often accompanied by calabash percussion. Tuareg Desert Blues, popularized by Tinariwen and Bombino, blends traditional nomadic sounds with electric guitar, creating a raw, rhythmic energy that mirrors the movement of the Sahara itself.
wp_post.post_title: Module 5 – Northern Mali: The Sound of the Sahara

wp_post.post_content:
The Mandingue and Fula peoples have some of the richest musical traditions in West Africa. This module explores their distinct melodic and rhythmic styles, focusing on how to translate kora and hoddu techniques to the guitar.

Learning Focus:

  • Adapting Mandingue kora-inspired melodies to guitar.
  • Exploring Djelimady Tounkara’s phrasing and improvisational approach.
  • Learning Fula ornamentation, alternate tunings, and microtonal phrasing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

The Mandingue griots have preserved their musical heritage through instruments like the kora, balafon, and ngoni. Meanwhile, Fula music is known for highly ornamented, cascading melodies that mimic the sound of the hoddu and flute. This module connects these traditions to the guitar.

Malian music is built on pentatonic scales, but they are not used the same way as in Western blues. This module breaks down how pentatonics function in Malian phrasing, groove, and improvisation.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring minor pentatonic phrasing with Malian nuances.
  • Understanding the relationship between melody and rhythm.
  • Studying the music of the Bozo people and their modal approach.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Malian pentatonic scales are deeply linked to the griot tradition. Unlike blues guitar, which leans on bending and passing tones, Malian pentatonics focus on repetition, variation, and hypnotic phrasing—drawing influence from instruments like the hoddu (an ancestor of the banjo).
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 – The Pentatonic Language of Malian Guitar

wp_post.post_content:
Before diving into Mali’s regional styles, you need to develop a solid technical foundation. This module focuses on the right-hand and left-hand techniques that define Malian guitar, from Ali Farka Touré’s signature phrasing to traditional Malian ornaments.

Learning Focus:

  • Navigating the fretboard through feel, not just theory.
  • Mastering triolets, slides, and hammer-ons to create a fluid sound.
  • Understanding how space and repetition shape Malian guitar solos.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Unlike Western guitar traditions, Malian guitarists don’t rely on fast runs or dense harmonic structures. Instead, the focus is on subtle variations, microtonal inflections, and a deep connection to rhythm—all of which stem from ngoni and kora techniques.

Malian guitar isn’t just about technique—it’s about understanding groove, phrasing, and storytelling. This module introduces you to the essential elements of Malian music, from call-and-response phrasing to locking in with the calabash groove.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding classic Malian phrasing and ornamentation.
  • Developing a deep, percussive groove with minimal notes.
  • Learning to improvise using cyclical, repetitive phrases.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Malian music has been passed down orally for centuries, preserving the stories of its people through griots—musical historians and storytellers. The calabash drum plays a crucial role in Malian music, establishing a hypnotic rhythmic drive that guitarists must learn to match.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 – The Foundations of Malian Guitar

wp_post.post_content: A series of masterclasses covering Cumbia, Cuban guitar techniques, and rhythmic approaches in Latin American music.

This module takes a deeper dive into advanced Cuban Son techniques, focusing on interpretation, groove, and melodic movement.

Learning Focus:

  • Learning Pablo Milanés’ De Qué Callada Manera.
  • Applying melodic variations and right-hand rhythmic flexibility.
  • Mastering intro sections and transition phrases.

This module refines left and right-hand control with chord exercises, extensions, and melodic phrasing drills.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring extensions and inversions for richer harmonic movement.

Strengthening chord transitions and hand coordination.

Bambuco is a Colombian Andean style with a distinctive rhythmic pulse and flowing melodies. This module explores how to translate its characteristic phrasing onto the guitar.

Learning Focus:

  • Learning Andean strumming patterns and rhythmic accents.
  • Combining melody, bass, and harmony into a single arrangement.
  • Exploring major and minor shifts in traditional Bambuco pieces.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Bambuco has strong Indigenous and Spanish roots, often performed in waltz-like rhythms but with a unique offbeat phrasing that sets it apart from European styles.

wp_post.post_content:
Cuban Son is one of the most influential styles in Latin music, forming the foundation for salsa and many Afro-Cuban rhythms. This module explores its clave-based groove and syncopated strumming techniques.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the clave rhythm and its role in Cuban Son.
  • Applying right-hand variations for rhythmic flexibility.
  • Using chord substitutions and reharmonization to add color.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Cuban Son blends African rhythmic traditions with Spanish harmonic influences. Made famous worldwide by artists like Buena Vista Social Club, it is known for its laid-back yet highly syncopated feel.
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 - How To Play Cuban Son

wp_post.post_content:
This module provides essential technique-building exercises to strengthen rhythm, coordination, and fretboard awareness.

Learning Focus:

  • Finger-strengthening chromatic exercises.
  • Metronome practice for developing precise rhythmic feel.
  • Chord familiarity and left-hand movement drills.

Joropo is one of the most rhythmically intricate styles of Latin American folk music, blending fast strumming, syncopation, and triplet-based rhythms. This module explores how to break down the patterns and reconstruct them for solo guitar.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Joropo’s triplet feel and right-hand strumming patterns.
  • Developing bass movement and pedal notes to enhance groove.
  • Learning classic Venezuelan guitar phrasing and rhythmic accents.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Joropo originates from the Colombo-Venezuelan border and evolved from Spanish and Indigenous influences. It is traditionally played on harp, cuatro, and maracas, with its rhythmic complexity making it one of Latin America’s most distinctive styles.

wp_post.post_content:
For those looking to go deeper, this module expands Konkoba with advanced variations, improvisation techniques, and a full demonstration.

Learning Focus:

  • Extending the melody into a full thematic variation.
  • Structuring improvisation within the framework of kora music.

Performing a complete version of Konkoba with fluency.

Konkoba is a highly rhythmic, complex piece, requiring a balance of bass, melody, and syncopation. This module focuses on its core accompaniment and melodic phrasing.

Learning Focus:

  • Developing the Kumbengo (repetitive groove) that drives the piece.
  • Mastering Toumani-style variations in Konkoba.

Attaching melody to the bassline for a complete arrangement.

wp_post.post_content:
Derek Gripper’s journey into kora music was shaped by his study of Toumani Diabaté’s groundbreaking compositions. This module provides insight into that process and introduces Jaarabi, a signature piece from Toumani’s repertoire.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the transcription process from kora to guitar.
  • Studying Jaarabi and its characteristic phrasing.
  • Learning Kelefa Ba, the first song traditionally taught to kora players.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Toumani Diabaté is considered the modern master of the kora, responsible for bringing its music to international audiences while preserving its deep traditional roots.

This module expands on Lam Tooro, focusing on accompaniment, improvisation, and melody development.

Learning Focus:

  • Playing the full accompaniment with rhythmic confidence.
  • Exploring improvisation within the structure of the piece.

Combining Lam Tooro with Mansana Cisse to expand melodic options.

Lam Tooro is a foundational piece in the kora repertoire, balancing a steady bassline with an evolving melody. This module introduces its structure and teaches how to maintain groove while developing melodic ideas.

Learning Focus:

  • Keeping the right hand loose for fluid, natural phrasing.
  • Learning the scale and groove of Lam Tooro.
  • Integrating melody and bass for a cohesive performance.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Lam Tooro is a classic Mandé piece passed down through generations of griots. It embodies the storytelling and communal spirit of West African music.

To translate kora music onto the guitar, you need more than just the right notes—you need to capture its rolling basslines, interwoven melodies, and rhythmic phrasing. This module introduces the tuning, picking techniques, and rhythmic foundations that bring the kora sound to life.

Learning Focus:

  • Tuning the guitar for a kora-like resonance.
  • Developing right-hand plucking patterns for polyrhythmic flow.
  • Learning how to shorten notes and use hammer-offs for authentic phrasing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

The kora is traditionally played by griots, the storytellers and musicians of West Africa. Its layered, cyclical melodies create a hypnotic effect, making it a cornerstone of Mandé musical traditions.

wp_post.post_content: Dedicated backing tracks for Raga Bhupali, Bhairavi, Khamaj, and Chandrakauns, recorded at multiple tempos for practice and improvisation.

Raga Chandrakauns is a deeply meditative raga known for its haunting atmosphere. This module explores its unique scale, phrasing, and rhythmic characteristics.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the structure of Tintal rhythm.
  • Learning the Sthai (first part) and Antara (second part) of the melody.
  • Applying complex Tihai variations for rhythmic resolution.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Chandrakauns is often performed in late-night concerts, evoking introspection and stillness. Its minor tonal center creates a sound that is both mysterious and hypnotic.

Raga Khamaj is known for its graceful, romantic character and fluid melodic movements. This module explores its phrasing, embellishments, and rhythmic structures.

Learning Focus:

  • Studying the Dadra Taal cycle and how it shapes phrasing.
  • Learning traditional melodies and improvisational patterns.
  • Applying Tane (fast melodic runs) and meend techniques.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Khamaj is frequently used in semi-classical forms like Thumri and Bhajan, bridging the gap between classical raga and folk traditions.

wp_post.post_content: Dedicated backing tracks for Raga Bhupali, Bhairavi, Khamaj, and Chandrakauns, recorded at multiple tempos for practice and improvisation.
An in-depth session covering advanced raga phrasing, improvisation techniques, and student Q&A.

Raga Bhairavi is one of the most widely performed ragas, often played at the conclusion of a concert. This module explores its interpretation through a Dhun, a semi-classical light composition.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Dadra Taal and its rhythmic structure.
  • Developing phrasing techniques for melodic flow.
  • Applying ornamentation to create expressive slides and bends.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Bhairavi is considered a universal raga, capable of conveying a wide range of emotions. It is frequently used in both devotional music and semi-classical forms.

Raga Bhupali is a bright, pentatonic raga often associated with folk traditions in Rajasthan. This module introduces its structure, melodic movements, and rhythmic applications.

Learning Focus:

  • Tuning the guitar for Raga Bhupali and understanding its scale.
  • Learning the Bandish (melodic composition) and Tihai rhythmic variations.
  • Exploring the concept of Alamkar (ornamentation) in raga playing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Bhupali is one of the most commonly performed ragas, often used to introduce students to Hindustani classical music. Its connection to folk traditions makes it an accessible yet deeply expressive raga.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - Raga Bhupali - Rajasthani Folk Song

wp_post.post_content:
Indian classical music is built on a rich system of melody, rhythm, and improvisation. This module introduces the fundamental concepts of raga, tala, and how they translate to the slide guitar.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the structure of raga and tala cycles.
  • Exploring the basics of Indian slide guitar tuning and technique.
  • Learning how to adapt Hindustani phrasing to a six-string guitar.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Hindustani music has evolved over centuries, absorbing influences from folk traditions, religious practices, and Persian musical systems. The slide guitar represents one of the most fascinating innovations in this tradition, blending Indian and Western elements into a singularly expressive sound.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - An Introduction To North Indian Music

wp_post.post_content:
• Master Class Recording: Access a recording of Justin Adams' live master class for deeper insights into North African guitar styles.
  • Ebook by Andy Morgan: Download and explore the history and influence of North African artists, including Bombino in the collection of articles compiled as Sounds Of The Sahara.
  • Master Class Presentation by Andy Morgan: Learn about the origins and evolution of Tinariwen from Tuareg rebels to international stars through stories and photos by their former manager Andy Morgan.

wp_post.post_content:
This module focuses on the unique tunings used in Desert Blues, particularly those employed by Tinariwen. You will learn to play Zahir Teneray using these tunings and explore the ngoni instrument with a demonstration by Justin Adams. Additionally, you will study Egyptian guitar melodies that reflect Arabic scales, adding another layer to your understanding of North African music.

Learning Focus

  • Desert Guitar Tunings: Study the unique tunings used by Tinariwen and apply them to the song Zahir Teneray.
  • Ngoni Instrument: Learn about the ngoni and its role in North African music, with demonstrations by Justin Adams.
  • Egyptian Melodies: Explore Egyptian guitar melodies influenced by Arabic scales and adapt them to your playing style.

Context & References

  • Ngoni: A traditional West African lute-like instrument, integral to various music styles across the Sahara. Revolutionised by Bassekou Kouyate.
  • Tinariwen: Focus on Zahir Teneray and the tunings characteristic of their desert blues style.
  • Umm Kulthum: Legendary Egyptian singer.
wp_post.post_title: Module 4 - Tinariwen Guitar Tunings, Egypt & The Ngoni

wp_post.post_content:
In this module, you will explore the traditional sounds of Moroccan Gnawa music, learning about its unique characteristics and cultural significance. You will study the traditional Gnawa song Ighzayel Mayel in both 4/4 and 6/8 time signatures, gaining insight into the adaptability of North African melodies.

Learning Focus

  • Introduction to Gnawa Music: Gain an understanding of Moroccan Gnawa music and its cultural significance.
  • Traditional Song: Learn Ighzayel Mayel in 4/4 and adapt it to 6/8 time signature, reflecting the flexibility of North African melodies.
  • Rhythmic Adaptation: Apply the adapted 6/8 rhythm to enhance understanding and performance.

Hear Justin alongside Gnawa maestro Mohammed Errebbaa
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 - Moroccan Gnawa Music and Adaptations

wp_post.post_content:
This module dives into the Moroccan 6/8 rhythm and its application in desert blues. You will learn to feel and play Moroccan 6/8 rhythms and explore Tuareg-style grooves inspired by Tinariwen. Additionally, you will adapt the previously learned melody of Abdul Kadir into a 6/8 time signature and study an Algerian track by Raina Rai, understanding its influence on Algerian guitar music.

Learning Focus

  • Moroccan 6/8 Rhythm: Understand and feel the Moroccan 6/8 rhythm and its application in desert music.
  • Tuareg Groove: Learn the style of Tinariwen, focusing on rhythm guitar patterns and syncopations.
  • Adapting Melodies: Adapt the previously learned Abdul Kader melody from 4/4 to 6/8 time signature.
  • Algerian Track: Study and perform Taila by the band Raina Rai, highlighting the influential Algerian guitar techniques of Lotfi Attar.

Context & References

  • Tinariwen: Tuareg band known for their innovative desert blues, blending traditional rhythms with modern influences.
  • Listening References: Taila by Raina Rai
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - Moroccan 6/8 Grooves and Tuareg Accompaniment

wp_post.post_content:
In this module, you will embark on a journey into the rhythmic foundations of North African music. Justin Adams will introduce you to essential Darabuka rhythms and basic North African guitar patterns, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of this musical tradition. You will also learn to perform the traditional Tunisian Sufi song Sidi Mansour, incorporating rhythm and melody into your practice.

Learning Focus

  • Introduction to North African Rhythms: Learn the basics of Darabuka rhythms to understand the rhythmic context of Rai and Sufi music.
  • Rhythm Guitar Patterns: Explore fundamental North African rhythm guitar patterns and their unique placement within the bar.
  • Tunisian Sufi Song: Study and perform Sidi Mansour, focusing on rhythm guitar parts, melody, and using backing tracks for practice.

Context & References

  • Sufi and Rai Music:
    • Sufi Music: Spiritual music used in rituals, characterized by its meditative and trance-inducing qualities.
    • Rai Music: Algerian genre blending traditional sounds with modern influences, known for its complex rhythms and expressive style.
  • Sidi Mansour: A celebrated Tunisian Sufi song known for its intricate rhythms and rich melody.
  • Listening References: The two songs studied in this module could be referred to as standards so you can find many different versions by different artists. Here are two popular versions below.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - Foundations of North African Rhythms and Sufi Music

wp_post.post_content:
In this final module, the La Perla trio demonstrates with a complete Gaita ensemble, teaching song introductions, rhythm performance, and the Merengue rhythm. The module also introduces the Llamador, a key percussion instrument.

Learning Focus

  • Learning how Gaita songs are introduced.
  • Performing the Merengue rhythm in an ensemble.
  • Exploring the role of the Llamador in maintaining rhythm.

Context & References: Llamador

The Llamador is a small drum that provides a steady pulse for Gaita ensembles, ensuring cohesion between the flutes, drums, and maracas.

Diana San Miguel demonstrates how to incorporate a second Maraca to create the 6/8 Fandango rhythm, while teaching stamina techniques for this physical instrument.

Learning Focus

  • Combining two maracas for rhythmic complexity.
  • Playing the 6/8 Fandango rhythm.
  • Building stamina for longer performances.

Context & References: Fandango Rhythm

The Fandango rhythm is a traditional 6/8 rhythm deeply rooted in Afro-Colombian and Spanish musical heritage. In Colombian Gaita music, it provides a lively, syncopated foundation, blending Indigenous, African, and European influences. The rhythm is both dynamic and intricate, often serving as the backbone of celebratory dances and communal gatherings. Its cyclic structure allows for fluid improvisation, creating a vibrant interplay between the maracas, drums, and flutes in a Gaita ensemble.

Diana Sanmiguel introduces the basics of playing a single Maraca, covering essential movements, rhythmic control, and variations.

Learning Focus

  • Controlling maraca movements for consistent rhythm.
  • Exploring rhythmic variations to add texture.
  • Understanding the maraca’s role in Gaita music.

Context & References: Maracas

The Maracas have Indigenous roots and are central to Gaita music, enhancing its rhythmic complexity with a connection to ancestral traditions.

Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: El Sancocho by La Perla

Roberta Leono introduces the Merengue rhythm, teaching its patterns, variations, and tempo management. This module explores its Afro-Colombian roots and cultural significance in Gaita music.

Learning Focus

  • Mastering the Merengue rhythm on the Tambor Alegre.
  • Adding rhythmic variations to enhance musicality.
  • Managing tempo for precise performance.

Context & References: Merengue Rhythm

The Merengue rhythm blends African drum patterns with Indigenous melodies. Its lively 2/4 beat is central to Colombian Gaita and Afro-Caribbean celebrations.

Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: Lo Flor del Melón by Sixto Silgado Paíto
  • Tambor solo: La boza de la máquina by Sixto Silgado Paíto

rank_math_schema_VideoObject.name: %seo_title%
rank_math_schema_VideoObject.description: Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

wp_post.post_content:
Building on the previous module, Roberta Leono teaches advanced techniques to strengthen wrist movement, improve finger dexterity, and create rich bass tones on the Tambor Alegre.

Learning Focus

  • Strengthening wrists and enhancing finger dexterity.
  • Combining strokes to create complex rhythms.
  • Producing a full, rich bass tone on the drum.

Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: Tambor Alegre Accompaniment and Solo
wp_post.post_title: Module 6 – Perfecting The Tambor Alegre Technique

wp_post.post_content:
Roberta Leono introduces the Tambor Alegre, teaching basic strokes, rhythms, and variations to create an open sound that complements the Gaita ensemble.

Learning Focus

  • Mastering basic strokes and rhythms on the Tambor Alegre.
  • Developing variations to add texture and energy.
  • Learning how the Tambor Alegre interacts with the Gaita.

Context & References: Tambor Alegre

The Tambor Alegre is a dynamic hand drum central to Gaita music, rooted in African traditions. It forms the energetic foundation of many rhythms in Afro-Colombian music.

Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: Bruja by La Perla
wp_post.post_title: Module 5 – Learning To Play Tambor Alegre

wp_post.post_content:
Diana Sanmiguel introduces the Gaita Macho, teaching its role in harmonizing with the Gaita Hembra. This module concludes with the full La Perla trio demonstrating how the Gaitas and percussion work together in a traditional ensemble.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding the harmonic relationship between the Gaita Macho and Gaita Hembra.
  • Learning how the Gaita Macho follows the Gaita Hembra’s lead.
  • Exploring the dynamics of a traditional Gaita ensemble.

Context & References: Gaita Macho

The Gaita Macho complements the Gaita Hembra by adding harmonic depth, reflecting the Afro-Indigenous influences of Colombian Gaita music.

Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: Traditional Gaita Ensemble Performance

Karen Nerak teaches the structure and nuances of El Fin del Mundo, focusing on mastering the trino (trill) technique. The module concludes with a solo performance of La Garza Prieta.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding the structure of El Fin del Mundo.
  • Mastering the trino (trill) technique.
  • Applying learned techniques in a solo performance.

Context & References: Jesús María Sayas

Jesús María Sayas was a legendary Gaitero and cultural icon who dedicated his life to preserving Afro-Sabanero traditions. His contributions ensured the survival of Gaita music for future generations.

  Suggested Listening

  • YouTube: Video Featuring Jesús María Sayas
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 – Song Study - "El Fin Del Mundo"

rank_math_schema_VideoObject.name: %seo_title%
rank_math_schema_VideoObject.description: Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

wp_post.post_content:
This module explores the registers of the Gaita Hembra, teaching techniques to transition between octaves, build finger dexterity, and sustain higher notes. Karen Nerak provides insights into improving your sound and expanding your tonal range.

Learning Focus

  • Transitioning between low and high octaves using breath intensity.
  • Strengthening finger dexterity through rudiments.
  • Sustaining higher notes for improved tonal control.

Context & References: Toño García

Toño García was a revered Gaitero whose artistry helped preserve Afro-Colombian music traditions. Known for his masterful playing and dedication, he brought the Gaita to international attention.

Further Study

  • YouTube: Documentary on Toño García
  • Blog Post: Learn More About Toño García

Karen Nerak introduces the fundamentals of playing the Gaita Hembra, starting with a performance of the track La Garza Prieta. This module covers breathing techniques, proper posture, the basic scale, and finger positions. To support your learning, we’ve developed a custom flute tablature system to simplify practice by indicating which holes to cover which you’ll find used towards the end of this module.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding the Gaita Hembra’s role in traditional Colombian music.
  • Developing basic techniques, including posture, breath control, and finger positions.
  • Using custom flute tablature to simplify scale practice.

Context & References: Gaita Hembra

The Gaita Hembra plays the lead melody in Colombian Gaita music. Traditionally crafted from cactus wood and adorned with a feather, it symbolizes storytelling and a connection to nature, reflecting the Indigenous heritage of Colombia.

Suggested Listening

  • Spotify Playlist: Curated Gaita Tracks
  • Performance Video: La Perla Live Performance

Popolipo Beniko’s phrasing is some of the most iconic in Congolese music.

Learning Focus:

  • Learning the most popular Sebene line ever recorded.
  • Studying Popolipo’s second-line variations.
Gain deeper insight into Sebene, Soukous, and Rumba guitar through an interactive masterclass and Q&A session.

Crispin Ngoy’s Rumba guitar style brings a softer, more melodic approach to lead playing.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Crispin Ngoy’s unique Rumba phrasing.
  • Learning how to create a second melodic line within a rhythm section.

This module dives into Niwel’s own approach to modern Sebene, blending traditional and contemporary elements.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring modern Sebene phrasing techniques.
  • Applying variations and improvisation within the genre.

Roxy Tshimpaka’s distinctive chord and interval movement helped define Sebene’s energy.

Learning Focus:

  • Studying 3rd, 4th, and 5th interval combinations.
  • Analyzing Roxy’s approach to Sebene rhythm and variation.

Alain Makaba introduced modern lead techniques into Congolese guitar. This module explores his interval-based approach.

Learning Focus:

  • Breaking down Makaba’s signature interval phrasing.
  • Incorporating arpeggios into Sebene lines.
Gain deeper insight into Sebene, Soukous, and Rumba guitar through an interactive masterclass and Q&A session.
Practice your Sebene and Soukous grooves with authentic backing tracks designed to lock in your feel and timing.

This module focuses on bringing everything together—combining rhythm, melody, and lead playing in a structured way.

Learning Focus:

  • Using intervals and chromatic variations for more dynamic phrasing.
  • Creating strong, original guitar lines within a Soukous groove.
  • Studying fingerstyle rhythm techniques from OK Jazz.

Cultural & Musical Context:

The Ba Kongo tribe’s music heavily influenced the call-and-response phrasing in Sebene and Rumba guitar. Understanding these roots helps develop a more authentic approach.

This module expands your understanding of Sebene and Soukous, introducing you to guitar lines from key artists over the last 50 years.

Learning Focus:

  • Analyzing Sebene techniques from different eras.
  • Studying Roxy Tshimpaka’s signature phrasing.
  • Exploring the modern Soukous guitar approach of Wenge Musica.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Sebene and Soukous have evolved dramatically, from Franco’s early phrasing to the high-speed, intricate lines of modern Congolese bands.

Sebene is the high-energy, improvisational guitar section that defines Congolese music. This module explores how Sebene is structured, how to play it with clarity and groove, and how to combine rhythm and lead guitar effectively.

Learning Focus:

  • Studying the Sebene style of Zaiko Langa Langa.
  • Developing fluidity in lead guitar phrasing.
  • Understanding how to combine different rhythmic and melodic elements.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Sebene evolved from traditional Rumba breaks, becoming a standalone improvisational section in Soukous music. It remains one of the most recognizable and influential styles in African guitar playing.

This final module takes a deep dive into traditional Congolese drumming, bringing village rhythms onto the drum kit.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring the polyrhythmic structures of Kintweni, Zebola, and Agwaya.
  • Learning how to adapt hand percussion grooves to the drum kit.
  • Refining your rhythmic phrasing for expressive playing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Congolese drumming is rooted in centuries-old traditions, influencing everything from Rumba to Soukous. Understanding these rhythms provides a deeper connection to the roots of African groove.
wp_post.post_title: Module 6 - Traditional Congolese Drum Kit Rhythms

wp_post.post_content:
Bikutsi is a powerful rhythm from Cameroon, built on an infectious 9/8 time signature. This module explores its unique phrasing and drum kit adaptation.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Bikutsi’s rhythmic foundation and phrasing.
  • Applying hi-hat and snare variations for a full groove.
  • Performing Bikutsi rhythms in both traditional and modern contexts.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Bikutsi evolved from traditional Ewondo percussion into a genre that dominates Cameroonian music. Its driving pulse and layered polyrhythms make it one of Africa’s most powerful drumming styles.

Mutuashi is a rhythmically intricate dance groove originating from the Luba people of Congo. This module breaks down its syncopation, dynamic flow, and ensemble role.

Learning Focus:

  • Developing the Mutuashi groove with hi-hat ghost notes and rimshot variations.
  • Applying double kick and hi-hat phrasing for groove depth.
  • Combining variations to maintain rhythmic interest.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Mutuashi is a celebratory dance rhythm known for its fluid phrasing and expressive feel. Mastering it requires a deep sense of groove and control over subtle dynamics.
Practice your grooves with authentic African backing tracks, designed to help you internalize the feel and phrasing of each style.

wp_post.post_title: Sebene Heaven - The Bitter-Sweet Paradox Of Congolese Music

wp_post.post_content: A deep-dive session exploring advanced rhythmic concepts, performance techniques, and ensemble playing in Congolese drumming

A drummer’s ability to lock in with other musicians is what sets great players apart. This module focuses on how to integrate Congolese drum kit rhythms into a full band setting.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring 6/8 grooves found in Folklore, Bikutsi, and Suede rhythms.
  • Adapting alternative Soukous grooves to create variety in your playing.
  • Understanding the role of the drum kit within a full band arrangement.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Congolese drumming is deeply interactive. Drummers don’t just keep time—they converse with bass, guitar, and vocals, shaping the entire performance.
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 - Combining Your New Skills With The Ensemble

wp_post.post_content:
Rhythmic intensity is only part of the equation. This module explores how dynamics, groove shaping, and structural awareness bring Congolese drumming to life.

Learning Focus:

  • Strengthening kick drum stamina for endurance in high-energy playing.
  • Applying dynamic shifts to build and release tension within a song.
  • Structuring drum parts for the dancefloor, ensuring seamless transitions.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Congolese music is designed for dancing, and drummers play a crucial role in directing energy throughout a performance. Understanding when to push, when to pull back, and how to shape a groove is essential for authenticity.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - Developing Dynamics And Understanding Structure

wp_post.post_content:
Module 1 – Learn Soukous, Sebene, Cavacha & Zouk

The foundation of Congolese dance music lies in the interlocking rhythms of Cavacha, Sebene, and Zouk. These beats provide the backbone for Soukous and many modern African genres. This module focuses on developing the precision, stamina, and groove required to play these rhythms with confidence.

Learning Focus:

  • Mastering the core rhythmic structures of Zouk, Soukous, and Sebene.
  • Applying snare and hi-hat variations for a fluid, driving groove.
  • Developing fill techniques that transition seamlessly between sections.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Sebene is the signature high-energy dance section in Congolese music, while Cavacha’s rolling snare patterns drive the infectious groove of Soukous. Zouk, with its Caribbean influences, provides a smoother counterpart to these rhythms.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - Learn Soukous, Sebene, Cavache & Zouk

wp_post.post_content:
Go deeper into the history, culture, and evolution of Congolese guitar with these resources.

  • Sebene Heaven – The Bitter-Sweet Paradox of Congolese Music (ebook by Andy Morgan).
  • Congolese Guitar Masterclass – An in-depth session with Jeannot Bel (70 min).

Rumba Odemba is one of the most influential African music styles, blending Cuban rhythms with Congolese melodies. This module explores Franco’s signature lead guitar style and how Rumba evolved into African Salsa.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the clave-based rhythm of Rumba Odemba.
  • Learning Franco’s interval-based lead guitar technique.
  • Applying hybrid picking for fluid melodic phrasing.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Originally inspired by Cuban Son, Congolese Rumba became a dominant force in African music. The genre evolved with artists like Franco, Tabu Ley, and Pepe Kalle, influencing countless styles across the continent.

Sebene is the driving force of Congolese music, known for its fast, melodic guitar interplay. This module focuses on the chord progressions, lead lines, and phrasing techniques that give Sebene its unmistakable energy.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the structure of Sebene and its role in dance music.
  • Learning Trois Temps, Sept Sept, and Quatre Temps progressions.
  • Developing call-and-response phrasing between lead and rhythm guitar.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Sebene originated as a high-energy dance break in Congolese Rumba, later evolving into the backbone of Soukous and modern Central African guitar styles. Mastering it is essential for any guitarist serious about African music.

wp_post.post_content:
Rhythm guitar is the foundation of African music. This module lays the groundwork for Cameroonian Makossa, Zouk, and traditional Congolese rhythms, teaching you how to lock in with the rhythm section and drive the groove.

Learning Focus:

  • Mastering Makossa and Zouk strumming patterns.
  • Understanding rhythmic interplay between guitar, bass, and percussion.
  • Developing chord voicings and movement used in Central African styles.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Makossa, Zouk, and other Central African styles fuse African rhythms with Caribbean influences. Understanding these foundational grooves will allow you to adapt your playing to a wide range of African and Afro-Caribbean styles.

Maracatu is one of Brazil’s oldest Afro-Brazilian musical traditions, known for its powerful, processional rhythms. This module explores maracatu on the guitar, as well as Brazil’s evolving guitar traditions and influential pieces from major composers.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding maracatu rhythms and their application to guitar.
  • Learning Garoto’s "Lamento no Morro" for harmonic phrasing.
  • Exploring Brazil’s 7-string guitar tradition.
  • Adapting jazz standards into Brazilian grooves.

wp_post.post_content:
Samba is a broad genre with many regional variations. This module explores sub-genres such as samba de roda, partido alto, and choro, each with distinct harmonic and rhythmic characteristics.

Learning Focus:

  • Exploring Brazilian chord voicings and harmonic movement.
  • Understanding samba de roda’s call-and-response structure.
  • Learning partido alto’s syncopated groove and phrasing.
  • Translating pandeiro rhythms to the guitar.

Cultural & Musical Context:
Samba de roda has roots in Afro-Brazilian traditions and is closely tied to Candomblé and capoeira. Partido alto evolved through improvised samba battles, while choro became known as Brazil’s version of jazz, blending intricate melodies with syncopated rhythms.
wp_post.post_title: Module 3 – The Essential Sub-Genres Of Samba

wp_post.post_content:
Bossa nova transformed Brazilian music by blending samba rhythms with jazz harmony and a relaxed vocal and instrumental style. This module focuses on the unique right-hand syncopation, harmonic textures, and chord voicings that define the genre.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the core rhythmic feel of bossa nova.
  • Applying syncopated right-hand techniques for a flowing groove.
  • Exploring chord voicings and harmonic movement in classic progressions.
  • Learning and performing "Wave" by Antônio Carlos Jobim as a case study.

Cultural & Musical Context:
Bossa nova emerged in the late 1950s, pioneered by João Gilberto, Antônio Carlos Jobim, and Vinícius de Moraes. The genre’s international appeal led to collaborations with jazz artists like Stan Getz, expanding its influence worldwide.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 – How To Play Bossa Nova

wp_post.post_content:
Samba is one of Brazil’s most iconic musical styles, characterized by its infectious rhythms and syncopated grooves. This module explores the clave of samba, the rhythmic foundation that drives the music, and how it translates to the guitar. Through practical exercises, students will develop right-hand rhythmic precision, left-hand muting techniques, and harmonic movement essential to samba accompaniment.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the samba clave and its influence on phrasing.
  • Developing right-hand strumming techniques for an authentic groove.
  • Using left-hand muting to create percussive accents.
  • Navigating samba chord progressions and melodic bass movement.

Cultural & Musical Context:
Samba emerged in Afro-Brazilian communities in the early 20th century, evolving through Carnival celebrations and shaping global music trends. Key figures such as Noel Rosa, Cartola, and Baden Powell played a crucial role in defining the modern samba guitar style.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 – Samba – Clave, Chords And Grooves

wp_post.post_content:
Candomblé rhythms are deeply spiritual and tied to Afro-Brazilian religious traditions. This module focuses on Ijexá and other sacred grooves, teaching you how to blend them into contemporary drum kit playing.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Ijexá’s rhythmic structure and phrasing.
  • Combining multiple percussion voices within a drum kit setup.
  • Beginning improvisation within Afro-Brazilian rhythmic frameworks.
  • Experimenting with dynamic and textural variations.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Candomblé drumming is sacred music, performed in rituals to honor the Orixás (deities). Learning these rhythms offers insight into the spiritual roots of Brazilian percussion and their lasting influence on modern styles.
Learn how traditional Brazilian percussion rhythms are adapted to the drum kit, bridging the gap between past and present.

Maracatu is one of the oldest Afro-Brazilian drumming traditions, known for its deep, driving rhythms. This module focuses on how to bring the power of maracatu to the drum kit while maintaining its hypnotic, ritualistic feel.

Learning Focus:

  • Adapting Alfaia drum patterns to the bass drum and floor tom.
  • Incorporating Gonguê and Agogô bell patterns into kit playing.
  • Developing call-and-response phrasing for dynamic contrast.
  • Learning the Malê and Arrasto rhythms to build groove depth.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Maracatu has its roots in Afro-Brazilian ceremonial music, used in processions that honor African deities. Its intense, processional drumming style has influenced modern Brazilian genres and is a key element of the country’s rhythmic identity.
wp_post.post_title: Module 6 - How To Play Maracatu On The Drum Kit

wp_post.post_content:
Coco is an Afro-Brazilian rhythm that blends percussive call-and-response patterns with hypnotic grooves. This module introduces the clave-based structure of Coco and its powerful influence on Brazilian drumming.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding Coco’s clave-driven rhythmic foundation.
  • Developing foot independence for left-foot clave integration.
  • Applying bass drum phrasing to mimic hand percussion patterns.
  • Exploring floor tom variations and groove layering.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Coco originated in northeastern Brazil, shaped by African call-and-response traditions. It’s a major influence on styles like forró and maracatu, making it essential knowledge for any drummer exploring Brazilian rhythms.
Practice your grooves with authentic Brazilian backing tracks, designed to help you internalize the feel and phrasing of each style.
Explore the evolution of Brazilian drumming, from its African and indigenous roots to its influence on modern music.

Forró and partido alto bring a raw, dance-driven energy to Brazilian music. This module explores how these percussion-heavy styles translate onto the drum kit, teaching you how to blend regional grooves into your playing.

Learning Focus:

  • Adapting baião rhythms to the drum kit.
  • Exploring partido alto phrasing for syncopated groove.
  • Studying traditional Forró percussion (zabumba, triangle, pandeiro) and applying it to the kit.
  • Connecting samba patterns with other regional rhythms.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Forró is Brazil’s northeastern groove powerhouse, built around the zabumba drum’s deep pulse. Partido alto evolved through improvised samba battles, bringing a funk-like syncopation to Brazilian drumming.
wp_post.post_title: Module 4 - Forró, Partido Alto and Percussion Roots

wp_post.post_content:
Bossa nova is about precision, restraint, and swing. Unlike samba’s driving energy, bossa nova creates a laid-back feel through syncopation and delicate dynamics. This module focuses on playing bossa nova rhythms with finesse and control.

Learning Focus:

  • Developing the classic bossa nova rhythm with smooth syncopation.
  • Perfecting brush technique for subtle articulation.
  • Strengthening left-foot hi-hat coordination for groove consistency.
  • Understanding snare dynamics and phrasing for a fluid sound.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Bossa nova emerged in the late 1950s, fusing samba rhythms with jazz harmony. It became an international sensation, largely thanks to pioneers like João Gilberto and Antônio Carlos Jobim, influencing artists worldwide.

Samba isn’t a single rhythm—it’s a family of grooves, each with its own feel and cultural roots. This module explores samba pagode, samba batucada, and partido alto, giving you a deeper rhythmic vocabulary and stylistic versatility.

Learning Focus:

  • Understanding the groove-driven feel of samba pagode.
  • Developing speed and stamina for high-tempo samba.
  • Applying tamborim (hand drum) phrasing to hi-hat and snare.
  • Exploring samba batucada rhythms and their translation to drum kit.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Each samba subgenre has a distinct cultural and historical significance. Samba batucada powers Rio’s famous carnival parades, while samba pagode thrives in more relaxed, groove-heavy settings. Learning these subgenres allows drummers to move fluidly between different Brazilian styles with authenticity.
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - The Essential Sub Genres of Samba

wp_post.post_content:
Samba is the heartbeat of Brazilian music, driven by its syncopated grooves and percussive energy. This module introduces the foundation of samba drumming, helping you develop control, coordination, and the essential feel needed to capture the style authentically.

Learning Focus:

  • Mastering core samba rhythms on the drum kit.
  • Developing 16th-note phrasing and cross-stick variations.
  • Applying ride cymbal and caixa (snare) techniques for groove clarity.
  • Understanding 2/4 time signature and why it defines samba.

Cultural & Musical Context:

Samba evolved from Afro-Brazilian rhythms in the early 20th century, blending African percussion traditions with European harmonic influences. This driving rhythm became the backbone of Brazilian carnival, shaping the energy of street parades and global jazz fusion.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 - The Basics Of Brazilian Samba Drumming

wp_post.post_content:
Dive deep into the West African blues, a tradition that has profoundly influenced global music, particularly American blues. Niwel focuses on the pentatonic scale, a cornerstone of West African guitar playing, and demonstrates how to infuse your playing with the unique phrasing, ornamentation, and syncopation found in the music of Mali and beyond. The lessons are set against a traditional 12/8 groove played by the band, creating an authentic West African soundscape.

Learning Focus:

  • Mastery of the minor pentatonic scale in a West African context.
  • Blues improvisation over traditional African rhythms.

Context & References:

  • Guitarists to Explore: Ali Farka Touré, Vieux Farka Touré, Samba Touré.
  • For a deeper study into Malian guitar, check out our course Malian Guitar Evolution by Vieux Farka Touré.

wp_post.post_content:
This module opens with an improvisational exercise where Niwel demonstrates creating a melodic line over a 1-4-1-5 chord progression. You’ll learn how to approach unique guitar line creation in the African context, with a focus on melodic phrasing and rhythmic syncopation. The second part introduces Coupe-Décalé, a vibrant genre from Côte d'Ivoire characterized by fast tempos and energetic guitar riffs.

Learning Focus:

  • Melodic creation in an African context.
  • Coupe-Décalé rhythm guitar patterns.
  • Context & References:
  • Coupe-Décalé: A style that emerged in Côte d'Ivoire, blending dance rhythms with modern sounds.
  • Artists to Explore: Mareshal DJ, DJ Zouk.

A lot of modern Coupe-Décalé has more of an electronic music focus and less emphasis on the guitar lines so it can take some searching to find guitar references.

wp_post.post_content:
Explore the infectious grooves of Afrobeat, a genre pioneered by Fela Kuti that combines traditional African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. Niwel will teach the essential rhythm guitar parts that give Afrobeat its distinct syncopation, as well as the lead guitar lines that complement them. You’ll also get an in-depth look at how these guitar parts interact within the band.

Learning Focus:

  • Afrobeat rhythm and lead guitar interplay.
  • Understanding the cultural and political significance of Afrobeat.

Context & References:

  • Fela Kuti: Pioneer of Afrobeat, blending African rhythms with political activism.
  • Artists to Explore: Femi Kuti, Seun Kuti.

rank_math_schema_VideoObject.name: %seo_title%
rank_math_schema_VideoObject.description: Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

wp_post.post_content:
In this module, you will learn how to perform the beautiful and iconic African standard Malaika, a song made famous by Miriam Makeba. Niwel teaches the fingerstyle chord-melody technique, where you play both the melody and the chords simultaneously, creating a rich and full sound on the guitar. The module concludes with you playing the piece alongside a band, offering a true ensemble experience.

Learning Focus:

  • Fingerstyle chord-melody technique.
  • Performing alongside a band.

Context & References:

  • Miriam Makeba: A South African singer and civil rights activist known as "Mama Africa."
  • Listening Suggestions: Malaika by Miriam Makeba. (Below)
wp_post.post_title: Module 2 - African Standard -  Malaika in Chord-Melody Style

wp_post.post_content:
In this introductory module, Niwel Tsumbu shares essential warm-up exercises that are foundational to his renowned guitar technique. You’ll begin by practicing interval scales in thirds, a key exercise for improving finger dexterity and hand coordination. Niwel will also introduce alternate picking, a pivotal technique in Congolese music, helping you develop speed, precision, and articulation.

Learning Focus:

  • Warm-up exercises for fluidity and strength.
  • Introduction to alternate picking technique.

This module is an ideal starting point to ensure your hands are primed for the intricate playing styles ahead.

Get to know your tutor by checking out his track called "Mindule"

rank_math_schema_VideoObject.name: %seo_title%
rank_math_schema_VideoObject.description: Enjoy the videos and music you love, upload original content, and share it all with friends, family, and the world on YouTube.

wp_post.post_content:
In this module, you’ll explore the fundamentals of the Turkish makam system and how to apply it to the guitar. You’ll learn how to retune your instrument to access microtonal notes, study the traditional 9/8 Aksak rhythm, and break down the melody of Kirklah Semahi—a piece that embodies the essence of Turkish folk music.

Learning Focus

  • Understanding makam Hüseyni and its melodic movement
  • Retuning a standard guitar to access microtones
  • Mastering the 9/8 Aksak rhythm
  • Ornamentation techniques for authentic Turkish phrasing

Cultural & Musical Context

Turkish makams are deeply rooted in Ottoman classical and folk traditions, with intricate melodic structures that differ from Western scales. Kirklah Semahi is a traditional piece performed in Sufi ceremonies, where its hypnotic rhythm and flowing melody create a meditative atmosphere.
wp_post.post_title: Module 1 – Kirklah Semahi - Introduction to Turkish Makams and Microtonality
Module 1 - Learning The Basics Of Something
